comment_text.mn63:2.1: Māluṅkyaputta was, according to Pali commentaries, the son of the lady Māluṅkyā of Kosala. Alternatively, Sanskrit dictionaries give māluka as the name of a people or a mixed caste, although I have not been able to trace any further details. His conversion is not recorded as he appears always as a monk in Pali. This discourse and MN 64 depict him as somewhat of a fool, but it seems that he persisted, and late in life sought teachings in meditation and ultimately realized arahantship, of which we have two different accounts (AN 4.257, SN 35.95). The latter contains an extensive set of verses attributed to him, which are repeated at Thag 16.5. A second set of his verses are at Thag 6.5.
comment_text.mn63:5.9: “Extract this arrow”(imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi): in his Ayurvedic text Aṣṭāṅgahṛdayasaṁhitā, Vāgbhaṭa devotes the entirety of chapter 1.28 to this procedure (śalyāharaṇavidhi).
comment_text.mn63:5.19: It would appear that dhanu is the general word for “bow”, of which cāpa and kodaṇḍa are specialized varieties. These bows appear with others in a list of weapons at Arthaśāstra 2.18.8. While it is not clear what these were exactly, kodaṇḍa is sometimes used for “eyebrows”, suggesting that the bow of that name was of the recurve type favored by horsemen, and the cāpa by contrast may have been straight.
comment_text.mn63:5.21: The identifications for these are from Ñāṇatusita’s notes to Bodhi’s translation.
comment_text.mn63:5.27: The animals bherava (“terrifier”, variant roruva “roarer”) and semhāra are otherwise unknown. The commentary explains them as “black lion” and “monkey”.
comment_text.mn63:5.29: Again from Ñāṇatusita. Note that calves lose their teeth, and the roots are evidently quite sharp.
comment_text.mn63:6.1: This is a double conditional, the sense being that if the pre-condition is met (locative absolute), the subsequent act would follow (conditional). The form echoes Māluṅkyaputta’s conditions, which is why the syntax here is more convoluted than in similar cases elsewhere.

root_text.mn63:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn63:2.1: Atha kho āyasmato mālukyaputtassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
root_text.mn63:2.3: ‘sassato loko’tipi, ‘asassato loko’tipi, ‘antavā loko’tipi, ‘anantavā loko’tipi, ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’tipi, ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’tipi, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’tipi, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’tipi, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’tipi, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’tipi—
root_text.mn63:2.5: Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṁ me na ruccati, taṁ me nakkhamati.
root_text.mn63:2.9: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā—
root_text.mn63:2.13: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā—
root_text.mn63:3.1: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn63:3.2: “Idha mayhaṁ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
root_text.mn63:3.3: yānimāni diṭṭhigatāni bhagavatā abyākatāni ṭhapitāni paṭikkhittāni:
root_text.mn63:3.5: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’tipi—
root_text.mn63:3.7: Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṁ me na ruccati, taṁ me nakkhamati.
root_text.mn63:3.11: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā—
root_text.mn63:3.15: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā—
root_text.mn63:3.22: ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṁ hoti yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn63:3.29: ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṁ hoti yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn63:3.32: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti, ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
root_text.mn63:3.34: ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti, ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
root_text.mn63:3.36: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā, ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṁ hoti yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn63:3.39: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
root_text.mn63:3.41: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
root_text.mn63:3.43: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṁ hoti yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn63:3.46: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
root_text.mn63:3.48: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
root_text.mn63:3.50: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṁ hoti yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn63:4.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṁ cara, ahaṁ te byākarissāmi:
root_text.mn63:4.3: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?
root_text.mn63:4.6: ‘ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
root_text.mn63:4.7: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?
root_text.mn63:4.10: ‘ehi tvaṁ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṁ cara, ahaṁ te byākarissāmi:
root_text.mn63:4.12: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇāti vā”’ti;
root_text.mn63:4.14: ‘ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
root_text.mn63:4.16: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’ti.
root_text.mn63:4.17: Evaṁ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṁ paccācikkhasi?
root_text.mn63:5.2: ‘na tāvāhaṁ bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
root_text.mn63:5.4: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’ti,
root_text.mn63:5.5: abyākatameva taṁ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṁ kareyya.
root_text.mn63:5.6: Seyyathāpi, mālukyaputta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhapalepanena.
root_text.mn63:5.7: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṁ sallakattaṁ upaṭṭhapeyyuṁ.
root_text.mn63:5.9: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ purisaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, khattiyo vā brāhmaṇo vā vesso vā suddo vā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.11: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ purisaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto iti vā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.13: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ purisaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, dīgho vā rasso vā majjhimo vā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.15: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ purisaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, kāḷo vā sāmo vā maṅguracchavī vā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.17: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ purisaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, amukasmiṁ gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.19: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ dhanuṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā cāpo yadi vā kodaṇḍo’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.21: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ jiyaṁ jānāmi yāyamhi viddho, yadi vā akkassa yadi vā saṇhassa yadi vā nhārussa yadi vā maruvāya yadi vā khīrapaṇṇino’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.23: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ kaṇḍaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā gacchaṁ yadi vā ropiman’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.25: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ kaṇḍaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa pattehi vājitaṁ yadi vā gijjhassa yadi vā kaṅkassa yadi vā kulalassa yadi vā morassa yadi vā sithilahanuno’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.27: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ kaṇḍaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa nhārunā parikkhittaṁ yadi vā gavassa yadi vā mahiṁsassa yadi vā bheravassa yadi vā semhārassā’ti;
root_text.mn63:5.29: ‘na tāvāhaṁ imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi yāva na taṁ sallaṁ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā sallaṁ yadi vā khurappaṁ yadi vā vekaṇḍaṁ yadi vā nārācaṁ yadi vā vacchadantaṁ yadi vā karavīrapattan’ti—
root_text.mn63:5.30: aññātameva taṁ, mālukyaputta, tena purisena assa, atha so puriso kālaṁ kareyya.
root_text.mn63:5.31: Evameva kho, mālukyaputta, yo evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn63:5.32: ‘na tāvāhaṁ bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
root_text.mn63:5.34: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’ti—
root_text.mn63:5.35: abyākatameva taṁ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṁ kareyya.
root_text.mn63:6.1: ‘Sassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṁ no.
root_text.mn63:6.2: ‘Asassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
root_text.mn63:6.3: ‘Sassato loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘asassato loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṁ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;
root_text.mn63:6.5: ‘Antavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṁ no.
root_text.mn63:6.6: ‘Anantavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
root_text.mn63:6.7: ‘Antavā loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṁ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;
root_text.mn63:6.9: ‘Taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṁ no.
root_text.mn63:6.10: ‘Aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
root_text.mn63:6.11: ‘Taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…
root_text.mn63:6.13: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṁ no.
root_text.mn63:6.14: ‘Na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
root_text.mn63:6.15: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…
root_text.mn63:6.17: ‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṁ no.
root_text.mn63:6.18: ‘Neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
root_text.mn63:6.19: ‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…
root_text.mn63:7.1: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
root_text.mn63:7.19: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti—
root_text.mn63:7.21: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti—
root_text.mn63:8.2: Na hetaṁ, mālukyaputta, atthasaṁhitaṁ na ādibrahmacariyakaṁ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn63:10.2: Etañhi, mālukyaputta, atthasaṁhitaṁ etaṁ ādibrahmacariyakaṁ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn63:10.4: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
root_text.mn63:10.7: Attamano āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn63:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn63:2.1: Then as Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
translation_text.mn63:2.2: “There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and turned them down.
translation_text.mn63:2.3: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.
translation_text.mn63:2.4: The Buddha does not explain these points to me.
translation_text.mn63:2.5: I don’t endorse that, and do not accept it.
translation_text.mn63:2.6: I’ll go to him and ask him about this.
translation_text.mn63:2.7: If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,
translation_text.mn63:2.10: I will lead the spiritual life under him.
translation_text.mn63:2.11: If he does not explain these points to me,
translation_text.mn63:2.14: I shall disavow the training and return to a lesser life.”
translation_text.mn63:3.1: Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkyaputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:
translation_text.mn63:3.18: that the cosmos is eternal, please tell me.
translation_text.mn63:3.20: that the cosmos is not eternal, tell me.
translation_text.mn63:3.22: whether the cosmos is eternal or not, then it is straightforward to simply say:
translation_text.mn63:3.32: that the soul and the body are one and the same,
translation_text.mn63:3.34: or is the soul one thing, the body another;
translation_text.mn63:3.39: that after death, a realized one still exists,
translation_text.mn63:3.46: or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists, please tell me.
translation_text.mn63:3.50: any of these things, then it is straightforward to simply say:
translation_text.mn63:4.1: “What, Māluṅkyaputta, did I ever say to you:
translation_text.mn63:4.2: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you’?”
translation_text.mn63:4.5: “Or did you ever say to me:
translation_text.mn63:4.6: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me’?”
translation_text.mn63:4.9: “So it seems that I did not say to you:
translation_text.mn63:4.10: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you.’
translation_text.mn63:4.13: And you never said to me:
translation_text.mn63:4.14: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me.’
translation_text.mn63:4.17: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?
translation_text.mn63:5.1: Suppose someone were to say this:
translation_text.mn63:5.2: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
translation_text.mn63:5.3: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …
translation_text.mn63:5.4: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’
translation_text.mn63:5.5: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that individual would die.
translation_text.mn63:5.6: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
translation_text.mn63:5.7: His friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat him.
translation_text.mn63:5.9: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the man who wounded me was an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial.’
translation_text.mn63:5.11: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know the following things about the man who wounded me: his name and clan;
translation_text.mn63:5.13: whether he’s tall, short, or medium;
translation_text.mn63:5.15: whether his skin is black, brown, or dingy;
translation_text.mn63:5.17: and what village, town, or city he comes from.
translation_text.mn63:5.19: I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the bow that wounded me was straight or recurved;
translation_text.mn63:5.21: whether the bow-string is made of swallow-wort fibre, sunn hemp fibre, sinew, sanseveria fibre, or spurge fibre;
translation_text.mn63:5.23: whether the shaft is made from a bush or a plantation tree;
translation_text.mn63:5.25: whether the shaft was fitted with feathers from a vulture, a heron, a hawk, a peacock, or a stork;
translation_text.mn63:5.27: whether the shaft was bound with sinews of a cow, a buffalo, a black lion, or an ape;
translation_text.mn63:5.29: and whether the arrowhead was spiked, razor-tipped, barbed, made of iron or a calf’s tooth, or lancet-shaped.’
translation_text.mn63:5.30: That man would still not have learned these things, and meanwhile they’d die.
translation_text.mn63:5.31: In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
translation_text.mn63:5.32: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
translation_text.mn63:5.33: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …
translation_text.mn63:5.34: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’
translation_text.mn63:5.35: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that individual would die.
translation_text.mn63:6.1: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn63:6.2: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is not eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn63:6.3: When there is the view that the cosmos is eternal or that the cosmos is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
translation_text.mn63:6.4: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.
translation_text.mn63:6.5: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is finite’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.9: ‘the soul and the body are one and the same’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.10: ‘the soul is one thing, the body another’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.13: ‘a realized one still exists after death’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.14: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.17: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’ …
translation_text.mn63:6.18: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn63:6.19: When there are any of these views there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
translation_text.mn63:6.20: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.
translation_text.mn63:7.1: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
translation_text.mn63:7.2: and what I have declared as declared.
translation_text.mn63:7.3: And what have I not declared?
translation_text.mn63:7.4: I have not declared the following: ‘the cosmos is eternal,’
translation_text.mn63:7.11: ‘the soul and the body are one and the same,’
translation_text.mn63:7.13: ‘the soul is one thing, the body another,’
translation_text.mn63:7.15: ‘a realized one still exists after death,’
translation_text.mn63:7.17: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death,’
translation_text.mn63:7.19: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death,’
translation_text.mn63:7.21: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’
translation_text.mn63:8.1: And why haven’t I declared these things?
translation_text.mn63:8.2: Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn63:8.3: That’s why I haven’t declared them.
translation_text.mn63:9.2: I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’
translation_text.mn63:9.7: ‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn63:10.1: And why have I declared these things?
translation_text.mn63:10.2: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn63:10.3: That’s why I have declared them.
translation_text.mn63:10.4: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
translation_text.mn63:10.5: and what I have declared as declared.”
translation_text.mn63:10.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn63:10.7: Satisfied, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn63:4.1: “Kiṁ nu → kiṁnu kho (cck, km, mr), kinnu (sya1ed, sya2ed)
